title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not include an acceptable description. Acceptable descriptions include the following.

  • The populations (on either side of the geographical barrier) are no longer able to exchange genetic material.

  • There is no gene flow between the populations (on either side of the geographical barrier).

  • The populations (on either side of the geographical barrier) are no longer able to reproduce with each other.

  • The populations on either side of the geographical barrier have different selective pressures/have different mutations/experience genetic drift in different directions.

The response includes an acceptable description. Acceptable descriptions include the following.

  • The populations (on either side of the geographical barrier) are no longer able to exchange genetic material.

  • There is no gene flow between the populations (on either side of the geographical barrier).

  • The populations (on either side of the geographical barrier) are no longer able to reproduce with each other.

  • The populations on either side of the geographical barrier have different selective pressures/have different mutations/experience genetic drift in different directions.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not include an acceptable explanation. Acceptable explanations include the following.

  • The speciation rate could have been lower than the extinction rate.

  • A decrease in the speciation rate could reduce biodiversity (even if extinction rates do not change).

  • Genetic biodiversity could be reduced (if species undergo selection), without an increase in extinction rate.

The response includes an acceptable explanation. Acceptable explanations include the following.

  • The speciation rate could have been lower than the extinction rate.

  • A decrease in the speciation rate could reduce biodiversity (even if extinction rates do not change).

  • Genetic biodiversity could be reduced (if species undergo selection), without an increase in extinction rate.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not include the prediction that there will be/has been a decrease (in speciation rates, compared with previous rates).
The response includes the prediction that there will be/has been a decrease (in speciation rates, compared with previous rates).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not include an acceptable justification. Acceptable justifications include the following.

  • Invasive species can outcompete native species/specialists for resources, leading to the extinction of many native species/limiting the ability of native species to spread to new habitats.

  • An invasive species can prey on and drive (native prey) species to extinction (which would prevent these species from diverging).

The response includes an acceptable justification. Acceptable justifications include the following.

  • Invasive species can outcompete native species/specialists for resources, leading to the extinction of many native species/limiting the ability of native species to spread to new habitats.

  • An invasive species can prey on and drive (native prey) species to extinction (which would prevent these species from diverging).
